text:
I wouldn't recommend them if you do not have a food processor since making them as here described seems to be a lot of work. But with a food processor just mix dry ingredients and frozen butter (cut in pieces) in processor, process it a few seconds until well blended, add wet ingredients and pulse it until well blended, add raisins or any other fruits or chips you like, just pulse it a couple of times to mix, take the batter out, pat it flat and cut your scones. The batter needs to be well mixed but do not try to get it smooth â€“ scones are supposed to look crumbly. Easy but so delicious! I omitted the raisins and added butter scotch chips instead - they were a hit. But I'm sure I will try a lot of different add-ons in the future. Great recipe!

I mixed these up using my food processor and the results were fantastic... and so easy..
put flour and dry ingredients in first... spin the butter around til it flakes... then add the sour cream, eggs and dried fruit..til it forms a ball... then proceed with the recipe as written.  I tried both apricots and cranberries... and the results were fantastic... So easy... and much easier than grating the butter.. and the handmixing... (I broke my right arm on November 3rd.. so handmixing anything is out for awhile.. makes holiday cooking inconvenient)... These could get to be addictive!!

text:
What a wonderful scone recipe.  These turned out just slightly moist and not dried-out like other recipes I have tried.  The addition of the orange zest and cranberries gave them a delicious, subtle sweet flavor.  Like another reviewer suggested, I made these in the food processor so the dough came together very well, very quickly.  But sticky is an understatement!  Be sure you generously flour your work surface, hands, and knife when shaping and cutting these scones.  This is the best scone recipe I've tried and it's a definite make-again and again!
Update 11/12/07: I have made these scones no less than two dozen times and they are consistently a big hit with everyone, adults and children alike.  I will never consider another recipe for scones, this one is the absolute best.

text:
Excellent basic scone recipe.  It allowed for substitutions nicely.  I used half white and half whole grain flours to up the nutritional value (1/2 cup oat flour and 1/2 cup whole wheat pastry four plus 2 TBSP ground flax seed.) I divided the dough in half and put chocolate chips in one half (alas, I hate currants and raisins!)and unsweetened finely shredded coconut & chocolate chips in the other half.  Mmm, yummy, and halfway healthy too. Some other suggested "additions" are: craisins and white chips, lemon zest and orange flavored craisins, hazelnuts and toffee chunks, walnuts and chopped dried apricots, coarsely chopped candied ginger and cinnamon, pecans and Kraftmaid caramels cut into fourths... use your imagination and create scones to die for!

text:
I used this recipe as a base for my espresso cafe and they are one of our most popular sellers.

I increased the sugar from 65g to 75g however and I do not use frozen butter and then grate it.

I initially started following this recipe as it was written and found it to be far too time consuming and labor intensive with the frozen butter.  It may work fine for home users but when I have 8 other batches of scones to produce as well as 15 dozen batches of bagel dough that's proofing that need to be pulled and shaped at a specific time, grating the frozen butter seemed to be an unnecessary step.

I melt the butter and they come out perfect every time.

My oven (non-convection, exposed elements at 25' above sea level) I bake these 5 degrees F down (395f) and at exactly 15 minutes on every batch.

I also lightly top them with raw sugar before baking.

The Cherry-Almond variant, I add a few sliced almonds to the mix and on the top for a bit of "bling" and I drop the 155g of sour cream to 105g, otherwise the almond extract makes the dough a bit too soft.

I also make a Maple-Pecan, Bacon-Cheddar, Jalepeno-Cheddar and Sausage-Chive version.

This recipe is a great base for any scone you want to make.  I would encourage anyone wanting to make scones, either at home or in their restaurant/cafe to not forget that scones aren't always just a sweet treat with fruits, nuts and berries, you can make them into a great small meal by adding meats and herbs.

Don't be afraid to experiment!

text:
I used salted butter and they were fine. The hardest part was hand grating the butter and the whole mix with your fingers thing I didn't go for.  So this morning I grated the frozen butter with my food processor, switched to the chopping blade, added the flour and just pulsed it a couple of times.  Dumped in the wet ingredients and pulsed just until combined.  MUCH easier, (probably took a total of 1 minute) and texture is the same. These are excellent!  For the raisin version, I suggest adding a generous amount of cinnamon.  The cherry/almond combination is wonderful.
I also did a lemon/blueberry and a lemon/cranberry batch but definitely use fresh grated lemon rind along with  lemon extract.

text:
I made these exactly as stated except I substituted fresh blueberries for the raisins, and I was much more generous with the 1tsp of sugar when sprinkling it on top of these before baking. I don't have a food processor large enough for these so I just used my kitchen aid stand mixer. If you mix the dry ingredients then add the butter on low speed it takes a few minutes but it breaks the butter up into small, pea sized pieces. Then when you add your wet ingredients you only need to mix it on low for a few seconds, just until it barely starts to come together. Then I dumped my dough onto parchment paper, placed another piece of parment on top of it to form it together and then cut it. These came out delicious and butter-y. I don't think ill ever use another scone recipe again... but next time ill use 1/2 a cup of sugar in the dough (plus extra for on top) if I use fruit or nuts in these because they weren't quite sweet enough for me. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Very moist, tender scone and ingredients and porportions were pretty much perfect. No need to grate the butter folks. Just cube up the butter, add to the flour and mix with your Kitchenaid using a paddle beater on low. After a few minutes, the butter will become pea-size then add your wet ingredients.  So easy to make in the mixer. I usually use regular salted butter and add 1 teaspoon vanilla. My favorite combo is making Orange Apricot scones.  I add tsp. orange zest to the flour mixture and finely chopped dried apricots. I then make a glaze using orange juice, powdered sugar and orange zest. So moist and keeps well all day.  I would suggest eating it all the same day or else it does get dry on day 2. I always get exactly 8 scones, bake for exactly 15 min.

text:
I really wish I could give this recipe more than 5 stars.  Tonight, I baked my first batch of scones and was delighted to find that this simple recipe was perfect and delicious!  The footnotes are a wonderful addition - as I smelled these baking in the oven, I immediately began thinking of how many different ways I could change them up.  The only thing "missing" from this recipe is storage suggestions...and I googled those :)  FYI - all sources are in agreement that scones are best at room temperature, but can be wrapped in plastic once cool and stored in the refrigerator for one day or frozen for up to 3 months (then allowed to thaw in its packaging and warmed in a 350 degree oven for 5 minutes before serving).  Anyway, thanks so much for sharing this recipe.  I will definitely add this one to my personal collection.

text:
These are the best and I make them all the time, always by hand and it is very easy. Once the butter is grated in, you just need to toss it around gently in the flour and that is all the blending it needs. I usually use yogurt instead of sour cream, but sometimes, if I don't have either, I add lemon juice to milk to make a sour milk and it turns out really well. I usually put an egg in a measuring cup and fill the rest with sour cream or yogurt and a splash of vanilla. The dough ends up softer, but I don't handle it too much and it always turns out. I often sprinkle the top with cinnamon and sugar just before baking and it turns out lovely and crunchy. I have used dried cranberries or chopped apple instead of raisins on occasion. After never having much luck with scones, it's great to have a recipe that my family and friends love!

text:
This was a very good scone.  I made these plain (without the raisins) and I also made some replacing the raisins with 1/2 cup frozen blueberries and another batch with 1/2 cup mini chocolate chips.  I took these to a multicultural night for the England table and they were a big hit!  I used a food processor to mix the butter with the dry ingredients and then added that mixture to the egg/sour cream mixture in another bowl, folding with a rubber spatula.  At this point it still had a lot of dry crumbly pieces.  I then put the mixture onto some plastic wrap and folded the mixture about three times until it all came together.  The plastic wrap is great because it helps keep everything from sticking onto your hands!  If you prefer not to use plastic wrap, even if the dough still seems a bit dry/crumbly, it bakes up very nice in the oven.  Your scones won't look as "nice" but they are still very tasty!!!  Even though the recipe says 8 servings, these puff up quite a bit in the oven.  I actually made two circles and cut those into 8 servings each making 16 servings and each piece was very large after baking.

You don't need a food processor! It is so easy to grate frozen butter and does not take long at all. I think it would take longer to clean all the pieces of a food processor, than it would to grate the butter with a box grater and use a couple of bowls. Follow the recipe!

These scones are wonderful! Flaky and yummy and the recipe is so versatile. I have made them with raisins, dried blueberries w/lemon, and dried cherries w/ almond extract. All are sooo good!

In fact I think I will use the technique of grating butter for pie pastry, too.

I changed this a bit but I'm sure the original deserves 5 stars too!  I used 1 C whole wheat flour, 1/2 C white, 1/4 C ground flax, 1/4 C wheat bran, only 1/4 C sugar, and 1 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp cardamom and 1/2 tsp ginger.  To the wet ingredients I add 2 tsp vanilla or almond extract and used plain yogurt instead of sour cream.  I've even used soy yogurt and they were still fantastic. After grating the cold butter into the flour I toss it around with my fingers then use a pastry cutter to cut it in.  I've made these without any fruit or nuts then made some with apricots then tried dried cherries and almond extract and also cut up fresh cranberries with almond extract. Even the variety with the raisins are delicious! Perfect everytime!!

I did some experimenting today. My outcomes show that this continues to be a great recipe! I loved this recipe.  I make scones all of the time and take them to work.  The idea of grating the butter is great (no pun intended) and I will use that for other recipes.  I used buttermilk and 1/2 tsp cinnamon with the cinnamon chip scones.  Then I had to make a second batch with chopped "candy melts" in orange and green for the grandkids.  They loved em! This is my new "go to" recipe for scones!!!

text:
Terrific scone recipe!  I have been intimidated by scones in the past (mine were always too dry) - but this is a great, simple recipe!

Grating the butter is key - odd - but important to get the butter evenly mixed into the scones.  Actually, i kindof forgot my butter for about 30 minutes until I worked it into the flour and it worked fine (albeit a little messy.)

I used cherry craisins and added 3 big shakes of dried orange peel.  The sour cream/egg mixture poured over the flour nicely and mixed up quite easily with the back of a spoon.  I barely had to use my hands at all.

I then split the mixture into two balls and flattened one to about 7" diameter (3/4" thickness)on parchment paper on a stone, patted granular sugar on top,  and sliced into 8 pieces.  Seperated them and then actually needed to cook them 15 minutes.  They were perfect and I love the smaller scone size!

This is a wonderful recipe, though I did make minor changes. Rather than grate the butter in, I simply cubed it and then used a pastry cutter to mix it in until the mixture resembled coarse meal. I made sure my hands were floured well and kneaded the dough a little bit so there was a more even distribution of moisture, rather than clumps of dry/sticky dough. text:
Great basic recipe that accepts variations/additions nicely. Here's what I like to do with this wonderful recipe to make it my own...I dice the 1/2 cup (1 stick) butter before I get started and put it in the freezer to chill, I use brown sugar instead of white, use vanilla greek yogurt instead of sour cream, put a little jam on top before baking and after baking drizzle on a powdered sugar glaze. I use my food processor...pulse dry ingredients, add chilled butter and long pulse a few times, stir the egg and yogurt together in a bowl and add to food processor bowl, long pulses just until the dough starts to come together. Pour onto counter dusted with flour and pat together to form a ball and continue to press into a circle, 3/4" high. Cut like a pie into 8 wedges and transfer to a cookie sheet lined with parchment. Using floured fingers, I press a circular indentation into each wedge and fill with approx. 1/2 tsp of jam (any fruit jam will work with this recipe!). After cooling a bit on a wire rack, I drizzle some powdered sugar glaze on top (approx.1 cup powdered sugar, approx 1 Tbsp of softened butter, 1/4 tsp vanilla and a bit of whole milk, stirred together, add tiny amounts of milk until you get that drizzle-icious consistency). Pour the glaze into a ziplock baggie and snip a tiny bit of a corner off, then let the drizzle flow out of the corner as you move back and forth across each scone.

I typically add some sort of flavoring such as vanilla or lemon also. text:
Oh. My. Goodness. I don't review very often, but this recipe is so incredible, I had to run to the computer to review!  When I actually tasted the scones, I genuinely giggled - they are THAT good!  I did tweak the directions, however, as I am much too lazy to do all that work.  I cut the butter into chunks, stuck it in the freezer for a while, then tossed them into my food processor (using the metal blade, I still haven't figured out what the plastic one is for).  I pulsed the butter until it looked pretty crumbly, then added all the dry stuff at once (including the zest of one orange), pulsed a while longer until it looked crumbly and well-mixed.  I then dumped in the wet stuff (I did also add a tiny splash of vanilla), pulsed it all until it came to a ball on the side of the machine, then  dumped it onto a floured cutting board.   I kneaded in some chopped almonds and dried cranberries, cut it into pieces, baked, and voila!  The most incredible scones I've ever tasted.  EVER.  

(I also drizzled a confectioner's sugar/water mix over them once cooled, but it's not necessary)

Thanks a million, Pam, for such an incredible recipe!

text:
This is a very good, simple recipe.  I followed recipe and baking instructions except I used dried cranberries and white chocolate chips.  I put dry ingredients in food processor pulsed added slices of frozen butter and pulsed until mixture was in small chunks. It is IMPORTANT not to over mix! Then I dumped mixture out onto a large sheet of plastic wrap.  I used the wrap to form dough into a round circle about 3/4" thick and cut into 8 wedges.  I placed the wedges on a silpat on baking sheet and sprinkled with the sugar. No flour mess to clean up. I am looking forward to making these many more times!

text:
awesome. I make a customised version of this by adding frozen mixed berries and chunks of white chocolate. You need to work quickly with the berries so that they don't thaw out and water down the dough. I usually eyeball the amounts but tend to use an entire large white chocolate bar and about a cup or so of frozen berries. It all depends on your tastes. 

Don't be too scared if the dough seems a bit more sticky than usual. I sometimes need to add just a touch more flour to make up for the liquid in the berries but they always come out fine from the oven.

text:
The best homemade scones I've ever had!  Sour cream may sound weird, but makes them soft and moist and taste absolutely delicious. 

I recommend brushing tops of scones with an egg wash to get the tops golden and crispy, and topping with sugar in the raw instead of granulated white sugar.  I also used fat-free sour cream, which was totally fine. 

I also modified this recipe to make my "savory" scones.  I used 1/6 cup sugar instead of 1/3 cup, and instead of any fruit, I added 1/4 cup of cooked and chopped bacon, 1/6 cup diced chives, and 1/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese.  Those scones were super yummy too!!

Melt-in-your-mouth kind of scone! I've made many biscuits but it was my first time making "scones", and I have to say, it wasn't as messy as others have described it. (I followed the recipe exactly, except I used half wholewheat flour and cut the sugar to 1/4 instead of 1/3.) Comparing to the biscuits I make, the dough wasn't sticky (or messy) at all!!! (I've done a lot worse/messy work.) Instead of using food processor like others mentioned, I cut cold butter into cubes and started mixing with the dry ingredients using pastry blender (just the way I do when making savoury biscuits). As mentioned in the instruction, I thought the dough was waaay too dry at first, but as I was working with my hand(kind of "kneading" in a way I guess?), everything came together and although I was a bit worried that the scones would turn out dry, they didn't turn out dry at all! Moist and flakey, the way my family like them! I put vanilla extract and half dried raspberries and half dried blueberries. I wish I had orange or lemon, but I didn't.. I will make them again with chocolate chips, dried cranberries and orange zest, raisins, dried cherries, etc!

text:
If you've found this, your search for the perfect scone recipe is over! Not that this recipe needs additional ratings to prove that it rocks, but I thought I'd share my healthier variation. I substitute Greek Nonfat Plain Yogurt for the Sour Cream - no fat, more protein, no difference in taste or texture! I tried with regular nonfat yogurt once and it didn't turn out as well because it wasn't a dense enough texture, so you must go with Greek. I also sub half whole wheat flour (the Trader Joes one is really good and not gritty at all). I usually make this with 1 full Teaspoon Almond Extract, 1/2 cup Toasted Slivered Almonds, and 1/2 cup Dried Cherries (chopped to distibute flavor more evenly). It's amazing even though that's not even one of my preferred combinations! Recently I began making a simple glaze with powdered sugar, warm water, a dash of lemon juice, and 1/2 tsp vanilla. Any variation you choose should be great with this recipe, though!

text:
UPDATE 02/24/14: One reviewer states not to bother if you don't have a food processor...IGNORE THIS ADVICE. I have been making these scones for years, exactly as written, without a food processor. It make take longer but it is certainly not hard, by any stretch of the imagination. If you do not own a FP don't let that deter you from making and enjoying these wonderful treats! They are delicious!

I just finished making a batch of each flavor. I've tasted one of each and I think my fave are the almond/cherry although all are delicious (even though I forgot the salt in the orange/cran batch)! I am hosting a bridal shower next weekend and the theme is an English tea party so I wanted to make scones from scratch. I am confident these will be a hit. If not, I don't have a problem eating them myself! The only things I did different was used salted butter (all I had) and soaked the dried fruit according to the flavor it went with (i.e. - soaked cranberries in 2T OJ, soaked blueberries in lemon juice) and threw the liquid in with the batter. I did an egg wash then sprinkled with sugar. I don't have a food processor so used an old fashioned pastry blender and it turned out great. Overall they were easy and delicious. I can't wait for the shower to see what the guests (and the bride-to-be) think of them!

text:
This is the best scone recipe I have found; I've been using it for years. I usually make the combination that calls for the dried cherries and almond extract. (I do increase the almond extract amount a tiny bit for more flavor.) Scones are intended to be a bit on the dry side, but not "unedible dry." This recipe is just right. I'm quite sure it's the sour cream that makes the difference. I'm also kind of perplexed by the comments from those who think it's too hard to make these without a food processor. I've made this recipe both with and without a food processor, and neither way is labor intensive to me. The key to making them easier to mix by hand is to use a cheese grater to grate the frozen butter into the flour mixture. This makes it much easier to work the butter into the flour.

text:
I love love love love this recipe.  It's so adaptable!  Don't have sour cream?  I've used vanilla yogurt.  Don't have eggs?  I've used EggBeaters.  Don't like raisins?  I have made so many combinations by now!  My favorites are white chocolate apricot (substitute dried apricots for raisins and then once they are baked, melt white chocolate and smear it on them!!) and cinnamon brown sugar (leave the raisins out, but add a healthy sprinkling of cinnamon to the dry ingredients and then before you put them in the oven, sprinkle with more cinnamon, brown sugar, and regular sugar)  YUMMMM!  But... caution.  Icing is a must on all scones in my opinion.  Just mix together some powdered sugar and water and drizzle it on them after they bake with a spoon.  It will take a little while to dry, but it's so worth it.  Sometimes I just eat them before it dries lol.  I use the food processor method.  SO EASY.  Pulse dry ingredients.  Cut up your butter into half tablespoon size and pulse it in there several times.  Add in your fixins and pulse that.  Then add in the wet ingredients (no need to pre-mix them) and pulse that until it looks like a solid mass of dough!  SO VERY EASY.

I used a Kitchen Aid mixer instead of grating the butter but if I'd had more time, I would have followed that part of the recipe exactly.  I made some other modifications too - instead of using a half C of sour cream, I used 1/4 C sour cream, 1/4 C vanilla Greek yogurt.

For the fruits part of this, I also some of my own partially dehydrated raspberries instead of the suggested raisins or dried cranberries.  I put the raspberries in at the very end and turned the dough over in the bowl only about three to four times to ensure that so that they wouldn't disintegrate completely but also so that I would get the full flavor of the raspberries.

If you want a little more 'umph' in flavor, I would recommend using an extract like raspberry (in this case) or coconut (something I'd like to try in the near future.)  I will absolutely keep this recipe and make these again soon.  Thank you so much for sharing!!

text:
After eating the best scone I've ever tasted at a superb breakfast restaurant in Clearwater, Fla (called Wildflower), I was on a mission to duplicate. That one was not at all dry or crumbly but tasted soft and somewhat moist while keeping a scone's true texture. This recipe is dangerously close. It's excellent.

I didn't bother with grating the butter. Instead I melted it and stirred by hand into the dry ingredients. I didn't find it difficult at all to mix. Added the zest of one orange, a 1/2 tsp orange extract and 1/2 c dry cranberries when adding the sour cream mixture. Rather than fool with a floured surface and rolling all the dough (what a mess), I floured my hands and scooped a bit bigger than a golf ball amount of dough and pressed it flat and into a triangle in my palm. Used parchment and cooked exactly 15 minutes. So, so good! At Wildflower, I had a plain scone served with a dollop of raspberry jam on top and fresh whipped cream--I'll try that next! All sorts of varieties possible with this recipe. :-)

text:
These were great! I made these in my Ninja blender. I put in the dry ingredients first and pulsed a few times to combine, then I added chopped refrigerated butter, pulsed some more. Then added the sour cream and egg and some lemon zest. I made my dough round on a pizza pan then pressed frozen blueberries into the top of the round. Used a pizza cutter to cut triangles into the round just before adding to the oven. I baked them about 19 minutes (a couple more than recipe calls for), then cut them again with the pizza cutter. The hardest part of this recipe was waiting for them to cool!

I was a little skeptical at first because the recipe was so simple that I had doubts about how they would taste.  Boy, was I wrong!  These are AMAZING! I've made them twice and both times they have been a hit!  First time, I used dried cranberries and white chocolate chips, yum!! Lemon blueberry heaven! I made this recipe as lemon blueberry scones with some minor changes. I only noticed when I went to add the sour cream that I didn't have enough, so I used 1/4 cup of sour cream and 1/4 cup of homemade buttermilk (whole milk + a squirt of lemon juice). I added 1 tsp of lemon peel to the dry mixture and 1/2 tsp of lemon extract to the wet mixture. I replaced the raisins with 3/4 cup of frozen blueberries. Instead of topping them with sugar, I made a lemon glaze with 3/4 cup of confectioner's sugar and 1 1/2 tbsp of lemon juice. They were SUPERB! I had a couple guests over for coffee, and we ate them all. They raved about them and asked for the recipe. I think I'm going to make another batch tomorrow! This will definitely replace my previous lemon blueberry scone recipe.

text:
This is definitely a keeper.  Using frozen butter made these unbelievable flakey, with a nice, crisp crust.  I found the easiest way to incorporate the frozen butter was to dice it with a knife, then put it in the food processor with 1 cup of the flour until the pieces were slightly larger than pea-sized.  Then, I added the other dry ingredients and quickly gave them a whirl, before stirring in the wet ingredients.  (I used fat-free sour cream).  I made 2 batches, borrowing from ideas submitted by others.  One batch had fresh blueberries, lemon zest, nutmeg, vanilla and lemon extract in the scones, with a powdered sugar/lemon zest/lemon extract/non-fat cream glaze.  The other batch had cinnamon and vanilla in the scones, and a powdered sugar/creme brulee creamer/maple extract glaze.  I topped that one with glazed pecans.  Both kinds were a "wow" at a potluck.  I look forward to trying other variations.

Great scone recipe!  Nice & moist.  I did a Peach Cobbler variation by adding 1/2 tsp. of cinnamon & 1/4 tsp. nutmeg to the scone mixture plus a little extra sugar.  I also added 1/2 tsp. vanilla to the sour cream mixture before combining all the ingredients. When it was finished, i topped it w/ a peach cobbler topping & made some Devonshire cream to go with it.  Absolutely Delish!!  Works great as a peach cobbler without being gooey & runny.

I come from a family that eats scones at least once a month for as long as I can remember.  We have tried many different recipes but none of them have ever called for sour cream before. text:
Delicious! Easy to add your own fruit, nuts, chocolate chips or other goodies. Using a food processor makes this recipe easy as a snap! Add all dry ingredients, pulse to mix, then add cold butter and process until cornmeal texture. Add goodies, I used dried cranberries, pulse. Finally add the egg/sour cream mixture or egg/Greek yogurt mixture works too, then process until dough forms a ball. Total prep time is about 10 minutes.

These can be made ahead to free up your time on the day of a big party!  I baked these, froze them, and warmed them in a 350 degree oven for a little less than 10 minutes the day of the big party.  It worked beautifully!  I *hate* to clean my food processor, so I took a chance: I substituted Butter Flavor Crisco for the butter, and mixed everything by hand with a pastry blender.  The result? This is one of the best things I have ever made, and I believe it's the recipe I have received the most requests for.

text:
I doubled up the recipe for my High Tea. I did increase the baking powder to 3 tsp and the bicarb to 1 tsp (my rule of thumb is 1 tsp of leavening agent per cup of flour). When I mixed the sour cream/eggs into the flour/butter, it was way too dry, so I added about 1/2 milk little by little until my dough was coming together and a bit sticky. The doubled up quantity yielded 32  2" diameter scones, which I brushed with an egg yolk mixed with 1 Tsp milk before baking.
The taste and texture are wonderful!!! Maybe next time I will reduce the sugar a bit though but that's my personal taste.

I tried this about 6 months ago and make them regularly now.  Absolutely perfect!  I use the beater bar with my Kitchen Aid mixer - it is no fail.  I took the hint from the cafe owner - mix the dry ingredients, turn the mixer on low and drizzle in the butter . . oh my gosh, it makes these beautiful little clumps, just like finger mixing.  Then I put is much more goodies - a good 2 cups worth (usually a mix of coarsely chopped pecans, dried cherries and craisins and raisins - pretty much what ever sounds good). . and sprinkle the top with slivered almonds and sugar.   I keep wanting to frost them, but they don't last long enough!   Don't be afraid to try the mixer method as the cleanup is way easier than the food processor!

These are the flakiest scones I have ever baked or eaten (and I am a pretty accomplished baker).  I did not have sour cream on hand, but always have Greek yogurt so that was only substitution and it obviously had no adverse affect.  I also made a cream glaze with a little extra yogurt and some milk and brushed the top of the scones with it before sprinkling with sugar. I used Demerara sugar (for sprinkling only) since it has a prettier, big granule look.  My husband is used to eating good food and knows I am constantly trying new recipes, but he made a point of telling me I had to keep this one and write down everything I did so I could make them exactly the same again - he's so cute!

text:
this recipe is awesome!  i never make scones or biscuits in the food processor (makes for tough dough), so the butter grating method is ideal for me.  i love a good cranberry orange scone, so i use 2 t. of fresh orange zest, and 3/4 cup fresh cranberries (chopped).  i add the zest & fruit at the end when i stick my hands in the dough.  i like my scones to be free form, so i barely mix in the fruit and form each scone by hand, barely pressing each one into a slight triangle shape before placing on a parchment-lined baking sheet.  i bump up the temp. to 410 and bake for the full amount of time.  i like my scones crispy on the outside and soft and tender in the middle.  these alterations give me the perfect scone, every time!

Really delicious!  Made the following changes: Used whole wheat flour instead of all purpose.  A little more liquid is needed if whole wheat is used, so I added 2T of additional milk.  Heated the milk slightly and stirred in 2tsps of instant coffee, and let that cool.   Used 1/2 cup Greek style yogurt instead of sour cream. After cooling, I melted additional chocolate chips and drizzled the scones with that.  Definitely I would make this recipe again and again!!!  Such a versatile recipe:)  I'll make this next time used dried apricots with sliced almonds.

text:
I heart these scones!!!  The sour cream makes them more moist than typical scones (which both my husband and I love).  Key is to not work the dough too much, or it loses that nice crumb when baked.  Every time I make these, we share with the neighbors, who absolutely adore them, too!  I find they don't taste very good the next day (they get soggy really fast), but since they don't usually even have a chance to cool, I still give them 4 stars!    I made a mistake with one batch:  do not use fresh fruit mix-ins.  I tried frozen blueberries, and I had a sticky mess of dough that didn't bake up right.  Only use dried fruit!

text:
These are delicious!  And I'm not usually a scone lover. I made a cranberry almond version with a lemon glaze (just what I had on hand)......I put all the dry ingredients into a food processor and gave it a whirl. Then pulsed in very cold, cubed butter until they were pea-sized in the flour.  Poured the flour mixture into a large bowl and gently mixed in 1/4 cup of sliced almonds and 1/2 cup cranberries to coat.  In a separate small bowl, mixed the sour cream, egg, and zest of half a lemon.  Mixed the wet with dry ingredients until JUST combined....The dough was VERY wet and crumbly.  Rather than rolling it out, I dropped ten 2-inch rough rounds onto parchment paper.  Brushed the tops with a little milk and sprinkled with sugar. Baked at 400F for 17 mins. When cooled, drizzled each scone with lemon glaze (1 cup confectioners sugar + 1 to 1.5 tbsp lemon juice).....These will be a staple in our house! Look no further for a scone recipe, this is it.

text:
These were so easy to make and absolutely delicious! As per another reviewer's suggestion, I didn't freeze the butter before grating it; using the large holes on my box grater quickly resulted in a pile of long, narrow strips of butter on top of the dry ingredients. I then put the whole bowl in the freezer for about 30 minutes to harden the strips of butter, and when  I mixed them in with my fingers, the butter easily broke up into perfect-sized pieces. Because they're in season now, I substituted fresh blueberries for the raisins and added 1 tsp of vanilla to the sour cream-egg mixture. I was nervous about baking the scones on the lower middle rack because I was afraid the bottoms would burn with the rest underdone, but I followed the cooking directions as given and they came out absolutely perfect!! I will definitely make  again!

text:
Excellent!  I made some modifications.  I used 1 cup white flour and 1 cup of wheat flour.  I decreased the sugar to 1/4 cup (more than that would make it too sweet).  I didn't use frozen butter, I sliced up a stick of refrigerated margarine.  I did 1/4 cup raisins, and 1/4 cup craisins.  I didn't realize that I didn't have sour cream, so I used low-fat rasberry yogurt.  Next time I might use all wheat flour (no white).  I'm not sure why people are using a food processor.  Mixing the flour mixture with my hands took at most 45 seconds.  Mixing the egg mixture into the flour mixture with a fork took at most 30 seconds.  It would take a lot longer to set up the food processor and then have to clean it.  Maybe using frozen butter makes it harder to mix.  So use refrigerated margarine and don't use the food processor.  Also, with refrigerated margarine you don't have to use a box grater.  That way you don't have to clean the box grater.  (You can probably tell I try to minimize clean up).

text:
This is a fairly simple recipe and tastes so good.  I've made it several times and made flavor adjustments each time.  I've added almond extract, orange zest, a layer of lemon curd, ginger and chocolate chips.  It's a crowd pleaser every time I've made it.  A little trick I've learned for getting the butter done quickly is to use a cheese grater on softened butter then freeze the butter overnight.  It makes them come together very quickly in the morning.

I literally JUST made an account on this site so I can review this recipe! This is my first time ever making scones and the simplicity and deliciousness of these scones warrants a rave review from me.  I didn't have a grater to grate the frozen butter so I just cut them up into tiny pieces, threw them into the flour mix and combined by hand. I also added dried blueberries (instead of raisins) into the mix.  The dough was a lot drier than I expected, which made it harder to shape and transfer onto a pan. I was really worried about how this was going to turn out because it did NOT look pretty going into the oven.  Final Product: DELICIOUS! Soft in the inside and a little crunchier on the outside, exactly what I LOVE about scones! My boyfriend and dad raved about them. I definitely did not expect so many praises on my FIRST batch of scones ever. This was a very simple recipe to follow, seriously almost fool-proof. Don't worry about it not "looking right" before you put it in the oven, it will turn out great!

My husband says these are the best he's ever had!  These are the first and only scones I have ever made.  Everyone loves them.  I have made them with currants, with semisweet chocolate chips and walnuts, and with dried red tart cherries and chocolate or nuts.  All are terrific! text:
Decided I wanted scones for breakfast this morning and this is the only one that I had all the ingredients for. They turned out great, and went together very easily.  I'm not a fan of raisins or currants in my scones so I modified the recipe slightly: - lightly chopped 1/4c of fresh blueberries - chopped up about 1/4c of white chocolate chips - added about 1/3c of flour (during kneading) to compensate for the blueberry juice - sprinkled the tops with turbinado sugar (so it was crunchier). - cooked them for about 25m since they were wetter  It makes for a sloppier dough, but get all of the ingredients in the original recipe assembled so you have your dough-ball, flatten it out, put the blueberries and chocloate on top, and fold it together a few times (this is where it gets messy).  During this step keep dusting the dough and the counter with the extra flour.  Keep lightly kneading the dough with the fresh flour until it's not sticky, then flatten and divide as described in the original recipe.  This works great with blueberries, as well as raspberries (frozen fruits are a lot wetter however, so you may need more flour)...not enough scone recipes out there with white chocolate.

I love making these scones because they are so easy and you can make so many variations of them. I like to put some Orange zest (i whole orange zested) and fresh cranberry's (about 1 cup dried or 1 1/2 fresh-fresh makes them moist)in mine then make a simple icing with a little orange extract in it to top them. I've also added a 12oz can of pumpkin to them and made a thicker icing to top those (powder sugar, canned nonfat milk and a little cream cheese about 3 oz and just keep adding sugar and milk until you get the consistancy you want)

I never thought it was possible to make a delicious scone, but now I do!  These are the best tasting scones I have ever had.  Very moist and a perfect complement to a cup of coffee or tea.  I have made these two times.  The first time, the only change I made was replacing the raisins with 1/2 cup mini chocolate chips.  The second time I again used chocolate chips (at the request of my kids), used reduced fat sour cream, and added vanilla since I read several reviews where vanilla was added; but honestly, I didn't notice a difference in taste.  I don't have a food processor, so I grated a refrigerated cube of unsalted butter, and then placed the grated butter in the freezer until I needed it, and then mixed it by hand.  So easy to prepare and does not take long at all!  I will be making many more batches in the coming weeks, and hope to try other additions as other reviewers have suggested.

text:
This is a definite "wow" recipe. I made with my 10-year old daughter, following earlier suggestions to top with a glaze. We made the orange/cranberry version, but increased the grated orange rind to about 3 teaspoons. This gave the scone a strong orange flavor we enjoyed. To make rolling out easier, we sandwiched the dough between two sheets of waxed paper. Then we sprinkled our round pizza stone liberally with corn meal (as you would for pizza). I peeled one layer of the waxed paper, flipped onto the pizza stone, then peeled off the other layer of paper. I cut the triangles of the dough right on the stone and just gently pulled them apart. We soaked the dried cranberries in about 1/2 cup water while we prepared the dough, then pressed the cranberries into the top of the dough after we had rolled it out. Our butter was cold, not frozen, so we were able to easily and quickly blend with our pastry cutter. I'm looking forward to sneaking in some healthier ingredients, but the white flour version is great for a treat.

Still for anyone that wants a mild cinnamon scone try this modification.

text:
Amazing and easy.  For a twist, add the grated zest of a lemon and 1/2 cup blueberries (gently fold in when dough is done), 1/2 cup chocolate chips, 1/2 cup dried cranberries and 1/2 cups white chocolate chunks, the possibilities are endless.  My Irish neighbors beg me to make them when they come down for weekends! I also make them into "Savory Cheddar Scones" by adding fresh chopped herbs from my garden (thyme, chives, basil...) and 1/2 cup cheddar cheese to replace the fruit.  Save a bit of the sour cream and egg mix to brush on the top and srpinkle with freshly shredded parmesan cheese.

text:
I had a craving for hot scones with butter and jam, so I whipped these up one rainy afternoon, and my sister and I shared them over cups of tea. Delicious! Also, they were extremely easy to make... took about 20 minutes prep time, 15 minutes bake time and we were eating them within the hour! Instead of making them triangular shaped, I took round cookie cutters and cut them into circles... looks very pretty and they can fit into the toaster once they get cold and need a heating up! One tip I do have is make sure you get them out of the oven in time: I left mine in a little too long... they were golden brown, but a little crispier than I like.

text:
This is a regular in my house.  I mix the dry ingredients in a food processor, add cut up frozen butter until it is in pea-sized pieces or smaller, and then dump it out to be mixed with the rest of the ingredients.  Instead of raisins I use frozen wild blueberries (wild blueberries are smaller).  I freeze these before cooking on parchment paper and then move them to a tupperware once they're solid.  Then I pop them straight into the oven from the freezer with a little sugar on top.  They take closer to 25 minutes to cook from frozen.

city:

region:

country:

text:
I have made these scones a couple times. (Making a few different types each time.) the first time I followed the directions exactly, only subbing out flavors. I made chocolate chip, blackberry vanilla, and blueberry. Everyone raved about them. The second time I made them I had to make some drastic substitutions. I was low on AP flour, so I used self rising instead. I did not add any baking powder or salt. When I went to knead and shape the dough, I used AP flour. I noticed no significant difference in the texture, or the amount the scones rose. I also didn't have sour cream, so I soured milk (1 cup milk/1 tbl lemon juice) and used that. It made the dough a bit wetter, but I made up for that by kneading in AP flour. They came out extremely moist the second time, I may continue to use soured milk in lieu of sour cream. For my flavors I made chocolate chip, cranberry orange with orange royal icing (craisins and orange extract, next time I want to add in orange zest also), maple pecan with maple royal icing, and strawberry lemon with lemon royal icing. I took them to my kids school and when I went to get my plates there were only crumbs and comments about how moist and delicious they were.

I made the cranberry - orange  version following the recipe. I doubled the amount of butter. I sliced and julienned the frozen butter with a knife instead of grating it. I tried to mix the mixture by using a food processor but it was more of a headache, since the food processor 's bowl isn't big enough to hold the ingredients, and the dry flour got push through the gap between its lid and its bowl, so the big mixing bowl with little effort of elbow grease worked just fine. I made the dough the night before, cut and shaped it into heart shape pieces, arranged them in a parchment lined  baking tray, covered them loosely with saran wrap, then baked them in the morning. They tasted delicious. I've saved the recipe so I can make it again. Thank you for sharing the recipe.

text:
OMG!!!  BEST SCONES EVER!!!  My husband is a scone junkie.  He loves them!  I decided to try and bake him up some for a surprise knowing that they will be a fail (he truly is a  'scone snob').  I made these on Thanksgiving morning.  He woke up as the raisin batch came out of the oven.  I offered him a hot scone.  He took one bit and simply said, and I quote here, 'these are the BEST scones..DO NOT LOSE THE RECIPE!!'.  I just about fainted.  After reading the other reviews here is what I did:  I melted the butter (I used regular salted butter) and added all the wet ingredients into my stand mixer.  Beat until well combined.  I sifted the dry ingredients, then added the dry ingredients to the mixing bowl and mixed to combine the wet and dry ingredients.  With the mixer on the lowest speed, I added the raisins and mixed to combine.  I did use parchment paper.  I also made the orange -cranberry.  I added 2 T of Gran Marnier to the wet ingredients.  He liked these even better then the raisin.  Both turned out beautiful and light and just delicious.  Better then store bought!  You can adjust this recipe to be savory also.  Such a versatile recipe!!!  This recipe is definitely a keeper!!!!!!

text:
Love this recipe! I did make a couple changes. I used butter from the fridge, cut into cubes and worked it in the flour mixture with a pastry blender. I also used vanilla Greek yogurt instead of sour cream. I have found that if you mix the ingredients and then knead them on the counter a few times,  like when making buscuits, before shaping and cutting the cooked texture is wonderful.  I also bake on an airbake cookie sheet for 25 minutes. After they cool I have glazed them with brown butter frosting or a spiced glaze.  Can't get enough of these!

text:
I made pumpkin scones with this recipe by  adding 1/2 cup Libby's pumpkin pie canned filling, 3 tablespoons sour cream (instead of half a cup), 1/2 cup raisins and used fresh grated ginger. Came out as nice light scones. Husband gave thumbs up. Make sure you freeze the butter for ten minutes before grating it into your flour mixture. And I scooped the scone batter with an ice cream scooper onto the greased cookie sheet (more like you would with cookie dough cuz dough was kinda sticky and wet),then put  in the freezer for 30 minutes before cooking. Dough hardened. I pressed these balls down a bit more like a fat cookie. And voila! (Apparently freezing before baking, helps the scones rise more and improves lightness so I read somewhere else on line). Yummm. I'll make again. I think I'll double the cinnamon and nutmeg next time around too.

text:
Update:
So this is my go to recipe for scones now. I use my Cuisineart to make the dough and it works great and in half the time. So far I probably made them a dozen times. They are everyone's favorite. 
Original review:
These scones came out great! Crunchy outside and soft fluffy inside. Easy to make too! 
I did use my Kitchenaid mixer to mix dry ingredients and incorporate butter and then added egg with sourcream and mixed it with the fork. I will use a food processor next time as it will eliminate the need to grate butter by hand and cut prep time in half. After mixing the dough with fork, you will need to kneed it with your hand a bit to make sure all the flour got mixed with other ingredients and prevent pockets of flour inside your dough (but gently and not too long). I have tried at least five different scones recipes and these are definitely our favorite. Saving this recipe for future use and will try different flavors as suggested.

These scones are amazing! I am a novice baker and these were very easy and really surpassed my expectations.  I used the food processor like most other reviewers. These are wonderful, will definitely be making again!

These scones were delicious and the recipe was very easy to follow.I grated the butter in which was pretty much effortless. The only measurement I changed is that I added 1 cup of raisins rather than the 1/2 cup from the recipe because we like raisins in our household. I set the oven timer to 15 minutes initially then I checked it and they were slightly too moist so I added another minute. Then I switched the oven off completely and let the scones stay in the oven for another minute.
I had never made scones before and these exceeded my expectations and were certainly much better than those I would usually purchase.
I will definitely be making these again and the variations from the footnotes.

text:
We liked these a lot and I didn't even have frozen butter. I just used what was in the fridge. No food processor either, really? Just mix all the dry ingredients by hand and stir in your wet ones. I, also, added a teaspoon of vanilla for a fuller flavor. The texture was amazing and I've tried a few scone recipes; some use heavy cream, others milk or yogurt, but this is the first one I've tried with sour cream. Makes a vey moist scone, not dry and crumbly. Also, you can brush the tops of the scones with melted butter or milk before baking. A drizzle of icing is also nice on the cooled scones. Put anything in them that you enjoy in your muffins, I used chocolate chips.

text:
I had volunteered to make 24 scones for a church function for this morning that started at 9 am.  So, last night I made three batches of scones, a low fat recipe from a book I have here, and I burned two batches.  The third, I watched very carefully and pulled them out of the oven at the right time, but they were dry and tasteless.  I decided I would get up early and make some muffins, instead, even though I had promised scones.  So, this morning I got up at 7 am and found this recipe and how many people tried it, so I decided to bite the bullet and try this one.  I made two batches, cutting each batch into 10 pieces instead of 8, and carefully watched them as they baked.  They looked nice coming out of the oven. (I didn't have enough dried cranberries left to put in both batches, so I put chopped walnuts in one and combined the chopped walnuts and the rest of the cranberries for the other batch).  To my and my husband's delight they tasted good right out of the oven.  But, I thought, the real test would be what they tasted like after they cooled and even hours later when they were very cooled.  I took my 19 scones to the church function (my hubby and I shared one to taste) and while the program was running, one of the ladies from the kitchen came up behind me and said they were the best scones she had ever eaten and wanted the recipe.  I guess I will be making these again for church functions and home, too. Thanks for the excellent recipe. :)

text:
I've made this recipe twice now (without a food processor) and I love it.  Using the box grater for the butter is such a good idea and easier than using a pastry blender. It always seems too dry at first, but as I work it with my hands, pressing it against the bowl into a ball, I think the butter  starts to melt a little and helps pull it all together. Since I don't use a food processor, I don't have any issues with the dough being sticky. In fact, I don't even put the dough on a floured surface. I just put it directly onto the cookie sheet, flatten it into an oval shape and cut it into 8 triangles. I separate the triangles a little to give them room to get evenly baked. No problems. The end product is delicious. (Also, I used dried cranberries instead of raisins)

text:
First time making scones and with over 1000 reviews and 5 stars, I'm glad I chose this recipe!  I used my kitchenaid stand mixer like others. I combined dry ingredients, added frozen cubed butter, but I'm sure refrigerated cubed would work just fine and put mixer on medium until I had small pea sized butter chunks. Added blue berries instead of raisins and mixed wet ingredients plus 1 tsp of vanilla like some others. Turned the mixer on some more and once it was mixed, pat out onto wax paper and followed recipe. I LOVE super sweet baked goods. These are not very sweet, but with the blueberries, it was still great. With less sweetness, my husband commented that one was able to taste the dough without being over powered by sugar. I agree. This is my first scone recipe and probably the last one I will ever use. This is going in the cook book tonight!

text:
We make these scones every week.  Instead of sour cream we use Noosa vanilla, honey or lemon yogurt (depending on what type of scones we make).  For Blueberry scones we use dried blueberries 5 oz, lemon zest and lemon yogurt.  For Cherry Scones we use dried cherries 5 oz, 1 teaspoon of vanilla and vanilla yogurt.  For Raspberry Scones use dried raspberries.  Raisin, honey and walnut are delicious, use honey yogurt.  We have also made Chocolate Chip Scones.
For a glaze, use cream cheese and jam with a little powdered sugar and a little melted butter.  Mix all ingredients and drizzle over scones. 
We make the dough and keep it in the fridge.  When we want scones we cut them and bake.  They are warm and delicious every morning.   ENJOY!  We are addicted to them.

text:
I made this recipe with the orange zest and dried cranberries.  They are delicious, and I will make them again.  However, I will change up the prep method.  I usually try to follow a recipe exactly the first time, which is what I did here.  But I do not like grating anything on a box grater, and frozen butter is no exception.  And trying to mix the butter into the dry ingredients with my hands was a total mess.  So terribly sticky that a large portion of the dough stuck to my fingers.  In desperation, I sprayed a little Pam on my hands, and I was finally able to get a ball formed.  From that point on, everything went smoothly.  The next time I make this recipe, I will skip the grating with a box grater and mixing with my fingers.  Instead, I will follow other reviewers suggestions to use my stand mixer or food processor.

text:
I made the blueberry lemon and the cherry almond scones. They were super easy and taste amazing. I make homemade biscuits all the time so instead of frozen butter I just used cold butter out of the fridge and quickly used my finger tips to incorporate it into the dry ingredients. The key is to work quickly so as not to melt the butter with your hands. The batter will be messy so have your sour cream and eggs pre-mixed so you can add them with messy hands. Scones are just sweet biscuits so you want a wet dough. Try to add as little flour as possible when patting out the dough for cutting. The less you handle the dough the better. I didn't have dried blueberries so I used frozen ones I had frozen from the farm. It was slightly messier than the dried cherries but tasted wonderful.

This is a good basic scone recipe, but I've made others which I prefer. To me they were a little bland; a splash of vanilla or some icing on the finished product might help. Knead the dough for about a minute to get it to come together. I made one batch exactly as written (soaking the raisins in apple juice beforehand). I then used this as a base for another recipe, adding a tsp vanilla and the juice and zest from a medium-sized lemon, omitting the raisins, brushing on a lemon-vanilla icing, and sprinkling with poppy seeds. This has potential.

text:
I've tried several different recipes for scones and this one tastes the best.  The most wonderful thing about this basic recipe is how versatile it is.  Instead of 1/2 cup Sour Cream, I've used various flavors of yogurt, mashed banana, blackberries boiled down with seeds strained out and then thickened with corn starch, and even guava paste melted down with some water added.  In order to get a denser consistency, I use 1 cup all purpose flour and 1 cup bread flour.

text:
My husband really really likes scones and he said these were the best he had ever eaten. Freezing the butter definitely helped. Thanks for the suggestion. I also chilled the dry ingredients before using my hands to rub the butter into the flour. Skipped dried fruit and added a little vanilla. Used a bit more sugar on top. I've made these twice and both times were equally wonderful.
Edit: I have since made these at least 15 times with good results. I vary the flavors for fun but use this as a base recipe. Bought bulk butter and sour cream almost exclusively for these scones. Next I want to try fat-free yogurt for something a little healthier. The only problem I've run into was probably a measuring error, getting the dough too wet. Be careful if you want to add extra liquid ingredients. Tonight I am whipping them up with my food processor instead of by hand and so far so good. The butter isn't as finely mixed as usual. I was worried about blending it in instead of cutting and rubbing like for biscuits. Both ways seem to work well though. Oh, and if you don't have a bench scraper, get one! They are so handy for pulling dough together and shaping, even cutting. Last thing if you haven't considered it: try using sugar to prevent club fingers. Sprinkle on dough before rounding with your hands.

text:
This recipe could not be easier. Threw all the dry ingredients into my food processor. I subbed one cup of WW pastry flour and added orange rind as well. Cut the butter into tablespoon slices and orange rind and pulsed until dough was coarse, then added dried cranberries and the wet ingredients and blended until it started to clump. Made 12 round balls and smashed with my hands. Cooked these on a silpat mat  and they done after 12 mins in my oven. This is a great recipe and my scones were better than any I have ever tasted.

None
text:
These scones are perfect!!    Suggestions:    1. Don't skip the step of freezing (or even grating, for that matter), the butter.  The texture is just perfec.   2. Use fresh fruits - I made these with raspberries.  Note that if using raspberries or even blueberries, the berry will break apart.  In order to make your batter not look hot pink, after rinsing the raspberries, toss them in a little bit of flower.  Even when I mixed and mashed these in the bowl as the recipe has you do with the dough,  the scones came out of the oven with that perfect golden brown color.   3.  Bake the scones on a pizza sheet (circular baking pan) covered in foil and lightly sprayed with Pam.  This way, the bottoms come out the same color as the rest of the scone.

I used half flour and half oatmeal, substituted Splenda for sugar, added lemon flavoring and lemon zest for the most tasty scone I have ever had.  So easy when it is all done in food processor.  Add dry ingredients to processor, toss in cold (not frozen) butter which is cut in chunks; process till crumbly; add other ingredients to make a ball of dough which is so easy to pat into shape, score or cut through, bake and enjoy!  Great recipe! Will try raisins or cranberries next but lemon makes a great scone.

This is a great recipe.  I don't grate the butter though.  I just cut it into medium chunks right out of the fridge.

A few great additions I use for the orange cranberry variation are: 1/2-1 tsp. of orange extract in the sour cream mixture; and also sprinkling liberally with course grained  white sugar for a crunchy texture with each bite.

I've also bought lemon extract and almond extract to try with the lemon/blueberry and cherry/almond variations.

I recently bought a cast iron mini scone pan - this seems to help ensure (general) uniformity in portion sizes.  Which help - considering I can eat half a batch in one sitting!

text:
I have tried several scone recipes and this one is the best so far, although I doubt I'll try any new recipes since this one is soooooo good!  I changed the order up a bit as I learned the more you handle the batter, the heavier the scones become (aka "rocks").  I cut the butter into the flour, then added everything else.  I was concerned because the dough didn't seem moist enough, but sure enough, if you keep pressing it against the bowl it comes together.  The scones are delicious!  I didn't sprinkle additional sugar on top before baking as I don't like too much sweet, and these scones truly didn't need additional sugar on top.  I suppose if you have a real sweet tooth it would be fine.  Thanks so much for sharing this great recipe!

These scones are delicious!  I've been making scones for 15 years, making for my Tea Club, and over 200 for Teas at  
my church.  I have always used a basic recipe that uses heavy whipping cream, very cold butter, and no egg.  I recently tried a recipe using buttermilk and one egg, and it was wonderful.  Then I tried one with buttermilk and no egg, and MELTED butter!  No cutting in the butter! I switched to using a food processor this step a long time ago, which is very helpful to women with arthritis in their hands or fingers.  It was also wonderful.  But with the melted butter recipe, I put all the ingredients in my Kitchenaid...didn't even have to use the food processor, just the Kitchenaid.  Okay, Now on to this recipe.  Today, someone brought these scones to our Sunday Adult Class...one bite, and I was hooked!  I can't wait to make a batch  tomorrow.  I am going to try it with  melted butter instead of frozen and grated butter.. My husband has humbly offered to be the taste tester. :)  If it doesn't work, then I'll use the food processor with frozen butter, but into small cubes....I can't do the grating.  I have been served many scone recipes by the other ladies in my Tea Club and at friends' homes, but none of them have been better, or even as good, as these.  If you don't like the idea of cutting in the butter, either by hand or by food processor, then try melting it, and pouring it into the center of your flour mixture.  I don't see how it made a difference in the two

Love this recipe.  I did not need to use my food processor.  I used butter straight from the refrigerator and mixed it in with the dry ingredients with my pastry blender.  Not hard at all!
Instead of fruit, I went for savory and added about 1/2 lb of chopped thick cut bacon, 1-1/2 c. grated Sharp Cheddar cheese (using the large grate, not finely grated cheese), and about 1/8 c. more sour cream to help mix in the bacon and cheddar cheese. You could pick up the entire triangle and eat it without it falling all over, so I think they were almost perfect.

text:
After having a white chocolate almond scone in a local bakery, I set out to clone it. This recipe worked beautifully! If you have a food processor, use it! SO easy! Mix your dry ingredients, add butter & mix, add wet ingredients & mix, then add your extrasâ€”pulse a few times and youâ€™re done! No grating butter necessary.              Now for MY version of the white chocolate almond scones, this is what I did: I used straight-from-the-fridge butter. I added 1/2tsp almond extract to the liquid portion of recipe, then instead of raisins, I added 1/4c almond slices & 1/4c Ghirardelli white chocolate chips. I sprinkled pure cane sugar on top & topped with a few almond slices too. I followed another reviewers suggestion and baked at 395 for exactly 15 minutes. These are light & airy & so lovely with a cup of coffee! The flavor is very subtle, though I suppose you could add a touch more almond extract if you choose. This was my first time making scones and it was so easy! I highly recommend this recipe!

text:
We're doing a Ladies Afternoon Tea at my church in a few weeks, so I've been reviewing many scone recipes. I decided I wanted to make some for a taste-test, and  I found this recipe that doesn't call for milk as most of them do, so I decided to try it.                                                                        I am SO GLAD I did!  It was very easy, and they were delicious. I made them exactly as listed; tried the orange cranberry (craisin)variation since I didn't have raisins.  I did put a light egg wash on them(saw this in other recipes to give them a golden color), and sprinkled a little sugar on top of that.  I let them cool for about 5-7 mins before I did my taste test.                                                            
They were not dry at all;  I thought they were perfect. I broke them in half and put a little strawberry jam and cool whip(haven't learned how to make clotted cream yet!) on the first one I tried.  Second one, I wanted to try plain, and it was good.    I know some of the other reviews mentioned needing a food processor; it's not necessary.     I cut each TBSP of butter into 4 small squares and mixed them into the dry ingredients by hand, and it was easy.  I will definitely be making this recipe again!!!

text:
Super easy and super DELICIOUS! I followed the recipe measurements as is, but used Greek Yogurt instead of sour cream. I also added a few special ingredients for flavor variations. As for the butter, I used super cold, refrigerated butter (not frozen) and cut it into the flour mixture with a potato masher, then a pastry cutter once manageable. 

The results were spectacular! The scones had a light crunchy exterior and a soft, but not too soft interior. They literally flew off the plates and within minutes, only crumbs remained. 

My Flavor Variations:
Cranberry-Orange with dried cranberries and orange zest added to dry ingredients, orange juice added to wet ingredients, topped with an orange glaze (orange juice, powdered sugar).

Blueberry-Lemon with dried blueberries and lemon zest added to dry ingredients, lemon juice added to wet ingredients, topped with a lemon drizzle (lemon juice, powdered sugar).

Chocolate Chip with extra large semi-sweet chocolate chips added to dry ingredients and vanilla extract added to wet ingredients. 

Almond (wedding cake) with sliced almonds added to dry ingredients, almond extract added to wet ingredients, topped with sugar. (next time I'll top with powdered sugar; that will be better) 

Cinnamon Spice with cinnamon, nutmeg and allspice added to dry ingredients, vanilla extract added to wet ingredients, topped with cinnamon-sugar.

As you can see, I have a sweet tooth. Next time I'll try savory flavors.

I highly recommend these with clotted cream or mascarpone cheese... And don't forget the jam! So yum!!. Start to finish was 30 min total... That's pretty hard to beat for homemade pastries.

These scones are amazing!  I took other reviewers advice and melted the butter instead of grating.  When you melt the butter it makes this recipe incredibly quick and easy! It only takes me a few minutes to make the dough!  You don't need a food processor or mixer.  I follow the directions exactly except I mix the melted butter with the other wet ingredients.

I have made this recipe before with grating the butter and honestly I cannot tell a difference in taste or texture.  It is just so much easier.  I also wanted to use blueberries so I dried fresh ones in  a 225 degree oven for 3 hours.  Delicious!

text:
I've made this dozens of times, always to rave reviews. I even invented a flavor -- "Hawaiian" scones -- which turned out so well I'd like to share: 

(...base recipe plus...)
1 tsp vanilla
1/2 cup diced sweetened dried pineapple
1/2 cup diced macadamias
1/2 cup unsweetened shredded coconut

I also sub whole wheat Einkorn flour (300g) which I grind myself, and brown sugar (75g) for the extra acid (gives more lift to the leaveners). I had some bad batches (too wet, sticky) when I was measuring flour and sugar by volume, so I've switched to weight (the volume equivalents are 2 1/2 cups flour, 1/3 cup brown sugar, I think).

Cheers,
Chris

text:
This recipe is a HIT. Every variation Iâ€™ve tried has been delicious and my guests are always so impressed!

A couple things I did differently:
1. Cold butter cut into chunks works great
2. Mix dry ingredients in food processor, add butter til crumbly, add wet ingredients. Done. So easy.
3. Bake on center rack and undercook JUST a little bit. (I do 13 minutes and they are perfectly brown on the bottoms/edges and moist on the inside.)
4. Make a drizzle out of powdered sugar, milk, and flavoring to go on top once they cook.
5. For the lemon blueberry I use 4-5 drops of lemon essential oil- gives SUCH good flavor, and easier/quicker than lemon zest. (I never have lemons on hand but always have lemon oil.) ???????

text:
These scones are perfect every time!  The sour cream keeps them them from being too dry.  
I do make a few changes to the recipe.  My only complaint had been the grating of the stick of butter, so this is what I do.  I keep the stick of butter in the refrigerator, cut it lengthwise into four strips, then cut the four strips into tiny chips, and put these chips in the freezer the night before I am cooking the scones.  I almost always substitute dried cranberries and orange zest for the raisins.  I mix these with the dry ingredients and butter chips in my food processor.  I live in Vermont so I also substitute maple syrup for the white sugar (I pretty much substitute maple syrup for sugar in every recipe that calls for the latter).  The maple syrup gets mixed with the sour cream, and egg.  I pour this sour cream, syrup and egg mixture  into the food processor while it is turned on and mixing the dry ingredients.  The dough is ready about the time the food processor bogs down! 
I have a non-stick scone pan that makes 16 perfect little scones                                                                        every time.  
This recipe has never failed to please!

text:
If you are looking for a simple fool proof recipe this is it. 
Have been poring over recipes for scones and had settled on another recipe. Measuring out the 4 and 2/3 rd cups flour called for  into a bowl,  I was overwhelmed by the massive amount of flour staring at me!! A quick perusal online brought me to this recipe and it was  a cinch to make. Not having a stick of frozen butter did not deter me. Grating a stick of butter from the refrigerator on to wax paper, sticking it in the freezer while getting the other ingredients together did the trick.  There was absolutely no need for a food processor. Took not more than a couple of minutes to rub in the butter to the flour.  Yogurt mixed with half and half was the only substitute I made since sour cream is usually not a staple in my fridg. Thank you !

text:
Loved this recipe with dried blueberries and lemon. I increased the amount of fruit by 50%...even double would have been okay. I don't like thins very sweet, but with this recipe, I think the extra fruit brings it up to the level of sweetness that I prefer. I also made it with dried cranberries and lemon, and another with 1/5 almond meal substituted for the flour, some almond extract, sliced almonds and dried cherries. Loved the recipe and will make it again. Tip: don't skimp on the sugar for the top, with the low level of sweetness of the scone, I think the sugar on top makes it perfect. I made 16 scones instead of 8 by dividing the dough and making two 6" circles. This was better for taking to a gathering where people like smaller treats. Baked for 11 minutes. Enjoy!

text:
YUMMY!  I've been making scones for years, but my normal recipe uses whipping cream.  I had a little sour cream that I needed to use before a trip and came across this gem.  It will be my new go-to scone recipe.  A few tips - I didn't freeze/grate the butter.  I cut it into pieces and used my pastry blender.  I also didn't mix it in the bowl.  I find it much easier to knead on a flour surface than in a bowl.  Finally, I used a rolling pin to flatten the top before cutting into wedges.   Just makes them a little more uniformly shaped so they bake more evenly.  I added cinnamon chips instead of the fruit and topped it with a cinnamon glaze.

text:
I don't use frozen butter or a grater. I cut butter with a knife then squeeze it into the flour. After dough is altogether I pat it into a rectangle and cut 3 even slices long ways and 4 short ways to make 12 squares. I then round them off between my palms with base on counter,   pinch tops, brush flour off bottoms and place on baking sheet. I bake them 13+ minutes at 400 degrees f.  Also, I sift the flour twice then re-measure 2 cups plus add a bit more. Best scones ever, so everyone tells me. 
If I don't have sour cream I use plain yogurt but a little less.

text:
I have made this recipe 8 or so times now.  It is fantastic.  I did make one change; I did not freeze the butter.  I used regular cold butter and used a pastry cutter to cut it into the flour mix, just like you would any flaky pastry.  
The resulting texture is somewhere between an American cookie and an American biscuit.  I am not sure what texture scones are supposed to have.  I polled native scone eaters and there was no consensus about the texture.  Some like it dense and dry, and some light and flaky.  So, I guess it is really personal preference.  This recipe makes a flaky inside and dry crunchy outside.  It is the best scone that I have every had, but I really don't like the dense dry scones.

Original 12/6/17 - Made these last night as written, using one of the author's notes for variation. It wasn't complicated at all. "Scones of home" (Blind melon reference) - making these made me feel like a master baker that should open her own shop in the middle of town and shout from the rooftops, "I can bake!!!". I will add this to my bag of baking party tricks when I want to impress someone. Best recipe ever!

text:
This is my "go-to" scone recipe! I throw all the dry ingredients in the food processor, give them a whirl, then add the butter (slightly softened) and whir that around. Next I add the dried fruits and nuts to chop them up slightly. Add the sour cream/egg mix and pulse until it comes together. EASY PEASY!! I think I take more time cutting them into triangles than I do making them, lol!! I do brush the tops of them with milk prior to baking and add decorative sugar to give them a "finished" look. Outstanding!!

text:
Have made this recipe several times and my whole family loves them! Very quick and easy and an excellent base for other flavors. Just the right amount of flour and sugar where it is sweet but not dry. However, I find that using a 1 cup raisins provided better flavor. Also, using a food processor for the butter saves time. Instead of using my fingers to blend butter into mix, I used a pastry blender and it worked quite well, if not better. Other than that, an excellent recipe all around, even when made with gluten free flour :)

text:
This is a good, simple recipe to start with. I used 1/2 c. margarine instead of real butter and it tasted fine. I added 1/2 t. vanilla and a dash of cinnamon to the dough.  I omitted the baking soda, and put in about two heaping teaspoons of baking powder. Instead of the sour cream, I used milk. You have to start with about 1/2 c. milk, and then alternate flour and milk until you get a dough that can be kneaded. I added 1/4 c. dried cranberries and 1/2 c. finely chopped walnuts. Knead on a floured surface about a dozen times.  I baked on an ungreased pan at 350 degrees for about 20 minutes, then frosted with a thin powdered sugar glaze. Good!

Best scones ever!!  I've tried most of the variations.  Super easy, no food processor required, really can't mess it up!!  I've tried it with the sour cream and substitute plain yogurt  a few times, I like the sour cream better.  
More substitutes I've tried are:
Salted/unsalted butter, I really can't tell the difference -- 
Frozen thawed/fresh blueberries or cranberries, seems the same -- 
I put some cinnamon or other spices into dry ingredients -- 
I like to squeeze 1/2 lemon or orange into wet ingredients makes little more moist, I like it better.  Still very good without it -- 
I sprinkle raw sugar and cinnamon on top before cutting into scones -- 
Super-duper easy, cannot mess it  :)

This recipe is so simple.  I made it all in my Ninja processor with the dough-blade.  I cubed the butter instead of grating before adding it to the processor.  

I also split the dough in half and tried two types of min-ins.  I did a blueberry-orange zest scone (1/4c. dried blueberries and 1/2tsp orange zest for half the dough), and a cinnamon chip scone for the other half (1/4c. cinnamon chip for half the dough).  Both turned out great.  Will be making this recipe again soon.

text:
I made this recipe using Pomegranate Craisins and Orange peel. It was delicious. I used salted butter from the fridge, cut it into the flour with a pastry cutter. This is very much the same process as you use to make pie crust, cutting in the butter to a cornmeal consistency and then adding the liquid to make balls of dough that you then make into one ball. I made two batches tonight. The first was perfect, the second had too much liquid and became sticky. Be careful how much liquid you add. The generous teaspoon of orange peel really made a wonderful orange flavor. I used my pizza cutter to cut the scones. Worked  great! For a quick glaze, I used the juice from the orange, powdered sugar, a little vanilla, and cinnamon.  It was wonderful .  These scones make a wonderful unexpected treat for any occasion. Yummy!

text:
I've made these scones countless times and they're always a hit! My dad requests scones for pretty much every holiday, or really just any time I visit my parents. Definitely don't bother mixing these by hand because, as others have said, it's so easy to whir up in the food processor. I do mix the liquid ingredients separately before adding them to the food processor, though, so I don't have to mix the entire dough quite as long. I always add vanilla to the liquid, and I've changed up the mix-ins many times. Chocolate chip scones are always a favorite, and I've made blueberry lemon, cranberry orange, etc.

text:
I loved this recipe super fast and easy.  I used vanilla yogurt and some whole milk instead of sour scream. I also don't mix my dried ingredients and butter together too much. The key to keeping scones moist but still not cake is to not over mix it. Just at the butter and use a potato masher to mix it up until its clumpy. Also, freeze the scones for 10 min before putting them into the oven! :D

text:
This was my first time making scones. I changed the recipe a little by using a blend of whole grain flours (Bob's Red Mill 10-Grain blend mixed with coconut flour and oat flour--about 2 cups), flax meal (1/4 cup), and regular flour (about 2 cups). I also used honey instead of sugar, so the dough was too wet, and I had to add about a cup extra flour. No problem! I used craisins and about a tablespoon of orange zest. I only needed to bake them for about 13 minutes. When they were finished, I drizzled them with a simple orange glaze (1/2 t zest, 2 T fresh orange juice, 1 c powdered sugar). People loved them!

Absolutely love this recipe. I passed it to my family and friends and its very popular now. Two things I learned to keep in mind. 1. Use refrigerated butter, not from freezer because they wont turn out soft. Refrigerated mixes way better with flour. 2. Don't over-press it in bowl. Be very gentle. The dough doesn't have to look like cookie dough - all smooth.
