text:
Like some reviewers said, it was tasty but the texture is more cake-like.  It was so easy to achieve with food processor.  Here is my procedure: 1) put all the dry ingredients including orange zest (if any) into the bowl and mix. 2) just roughly stir in raisins or cranberries and make sure they are coated with flour individually and not clumped. 3) cut in butter. It is fine to have little butter pieces. 4) add in sour cream/egg mixture and mix till a dough form with some but not much gluten. Don't overmix. 5) flour a 8" springform pan and pat the dough in. 6) flour a workbench and dump the dough from the pan upside down to the workbench to smoothen the top. 7) move it back to the pan and chill for 15 minutes (frozen butter will creat more steam which will help to puff up later when baked). 8) move it out onto a floured workbench and sprinkle 1 tsp sugar on top. 9) slice and bake for 14 minutes. I used 125 gm plain flour + 46 gm oat flour + 56 gm whole wheat flour to replace the 250 gm all purpose flour.  My girl and my mother in law like the orange cranberry version very much while my huppy like the traditional raisin version more. He likes the wheat flavor. Note: you may want to reduce the sugar used if using sweetened dried cranberry.

text:
Absolute 5 star recipe and I feel they are accident proof!  They are perfect as is, but my favorites are when I really change the recipe and make many healthier high protein, high fiber, little to no processed ingreds.  I have made these countless times and I rarely make the same way twice.  I always make in my food processor bc important to use the butter while still frozen.  I'm always sharing these and everyone raves about them and my husband never tires of them.
I always substitute 1 cup of white flour with 3/4 cup whole wheat flour and replace the 2nd cup of flour (this is where is its creative and accident proof so far) with 1/3 ground flax seed, 1/3 cup oat bran, 1/3 cup steel cut oats,...etc, just to total 1 full cup.  Then 2 scoops vanilla protein powder. Instead of processed sugar, I use pure maple syrup along with the wet ingreds and a teaspoon of vanilla extract.
I often substitute the sour cream with plain greek yogurt.
I add raisins, chopped dates, any dried berries, chopped figs...really anything you like and always add more than the recipe calls for because I love lots of fruit in mine.
My new favorite addition is 3-4 tablespoons matcha green tea powder for that extra antioxidant kick.
I LOVE THESE!!!!

Wonderful recipe. I read all the other reviews about grating the butter and here is what I came up with. I take a cold stick of butter from the fridge and grate it - takes 2 seconds, and all I have to wash is the grater. I put that butter in the freezer while I get the ingredients out and assembled. Mix in butter and the hundreds of different combos of add ins (thanks all for the ideas) and add the liquid. I do the first mix with a forks as the poster suggested and then use my hands to get it to a ball. It is loose but all that butter melts and holds everything together. Today was milk chocolate and cinnamon chips with some extra cinnamon added to the dry. My best combo yet. Thanks!

text:
I made this recipe for some friends with one modification: I used a heavy cream-milk-lemon juice mixture to substitute for sour cream, because I did not have any on-hand. I divided the batter in half, reulting in two batches: orange-chocolate chip and strawberries and cream scones. For the strawberries and cream version, I used food-processor-minced frozen strawberries. Because the strawberries were frozen, the yielded scones were more moist (something like a scone-cake hybrid), which I topped with a milk-powdered sugar glaze drizzle. The orange-chocolate chip scones (made with orange zest) maintained the typical consistency and texture of a scone (i.e. slightly dry), which would go well with tea. All in all, they came out well!

I made these scones and they were absolutely amazing!! I did change it up a bit though. Instead of sour cream, I used buttermilk. Instead of raisins, I used frozen blueberries. It was a bit messy, but they turned out amazingly light, fluffy, and moist. I wish I had taken a photo of them, but they didn't last long enough for me to get a photo of them. Haha!! Also, a hint: If you find yourself in a pickle (like I did) without an egg, you can substitute 2 TBS of Water, 1 TBS of Vegetable or Canola oil, and 2 tsp of baking powder, trust me...no one will notice the difference!! :) Enjoy!!

text:
These were okay. I have only made a couple of other types of scones in my life and they were way more flaky like and rich tasting. These were more like a slightly cakey overly-sweet biscuit. The tops of them appeared more bumpy than smooth to for some reason. I suppose, because of the stickiness of the dough. I think heavy cream, instead of sour cream, is the only way to go with scones. Only change I made was using golden raisins instead of regular. I just like their flavor lately. For some reason mine darkened on the bottom rather quickly despite baking on parchment. They went from underdone to overdone, on the bottom, in only about 2 minutes time. Towards the end I would keep an eye on them.

This will be a definite keeper!

Of all of the recipes that I have tried from allrecipes over the years, this is our very favorite.  When prepared as written, it delivers foolproof, wonderful, flakey scones.  Every time I make them, my husband gets a dreamy look in his eye and says that I should open a bakery.  Now that I've been making them so regularly, I use the base to make my own variations, such as lemon poppyseed. text:
Just made these. They are delicious! These are cake-like, not your typical scones. I left the raisins out and added 1 cup blueberries (stir these in last) and the zest of 1 lemon to the batter. I don't have a food processor so cut the cold butter into small cubes and cut it into the dry ingredients with a pastry blender. After the scones cooled I drizzled glaze on them (lemon juice, 10x sugar, unsalted butter, lemon zest). I will make them again, trying other flavors.

Fantastic! For those who do not have large food processors:
I cut my butter into little slices/pats before freezing. Next day, mixed my dry ingredients in my stand mixer; diced my frozen butter (honestly takes less than 2 min; it doesn't need to be perfect but just small bits of butter) with a knife and slowly mixed it into the dry. Used my hand to squeeze it together a bit more and followed the rest of the recipe as is. Not too much clean up and I added cranberries and orange zest and they were wonderful - not too sweet!

Incredible!  These scones are moist have a wonderful buttery flavor.  I have made this recipe at least 20-30 times, most of them by request from people who I've made it for before.  It has gotten rave reviews every single time.

In place of using a box grater for the butter, I cut butter straight from the refrigerator into the flour mix with a pastry knife.  I don't find it to be too much work at all.  Cranberry with orange zest is one of my favorites, but I can't wait to experiment more and more!

text:
Have never made scones before and not much of a baker, so take that for what is worth, but I thought the scones from this recipe were great. I followed others suggestions to put the egg in the measuring cup and then add liquids but it still needed at least 1/2 cup more flour (I wasn't measuring at that point) as it was too moist to kneed. I used 1/4 heavy whipping cream and 3/4 almond milk. I also added some dried orange rinds that I had grinded previously into a powder for some orange flavor. I also had to cook an additional 7 minutes to get them "golden brown" but ovens vary.  I will definitely make them again.

text:
Just finished making these scones and they turned out great! I would recommend not using frozen butter but just very cold butter. I did these in a food processor and my food processor couldn't handle the frozen butter but my blender could. 
I added cranberries, raisins, white chocolate chips and orange zest! 
Mine took about 19 minutes in the oven to cook - a little longer than the recipe stated. 
The mixture at first is quite sticky but if you use plenty of flour on the counter/surface and your hands then they turn out great. 
They were much easier to make than I expected! I will definitely be making more of these with more flavor combinations!

text:
Love this recipe! Have tried several variations and just cannot go wrong with ths simple recipe. We substitute the sour cream with Plain Greek Yogurt, so adds more protein to our morning. When you family asks for these every week you know they are good. They do turn out moist unlike other scone recipes. 
Trade: Greek Yogurt vs. Sour Cream
       More Baking Soda vs. Baking Powder (more cookie like)
       Essential Oil vs. squeezed juice
       Dried orange vs. fresh (I soak the dried orange in the egg and yogurt mixture to re-hydrate)

These are excellent! I've tried several different (highly rated) scone recipes with not so great results. These scones taste very much like the real thing. I didn't grate the butter, but cut it in with a pastry cutter. Also the dough was a bit dry (probably due to my lazy flour measuring), and I used a tiny bit of buttermilk to get it to come together. Dried currants, while sometimes hard to find in the south, are much better and authentic than raisins. 

Add some Irish butter and homemade preserved and you've got a yummy breakfast or tea time treat!

I made the Lemon-Blueberry version to go with some Lemon Curd I'd made recently. So delicious, even without additional accouterments! 
To address the review by melissathebaker who found the scones too cake-like, I found that as the days passed (I was the only one eating these, so they lasted several days), they got a little more dried out, even stored in a Snapware container, and became more of the biscuit-like texture she was seeking and never got stale. 
Highly recommend! I'll be making up a dry mix pack to go with the lemon curd I canned as a gift for a friend.

text:
This recipe is simply the best scone recipe out there. The scones come out slightly moist, and not dry like a certain large Seattle-based coffee shop's scones. I don't even bother with freezing and grating the butter. Just throw it in the bowl cold and work it with a pastry cutter until the mix looks sandy. My husband LOVES these, and I usually make at least one batch every weekend. They don't last through Sunday, though (because he and my 2-year-old go through them so quickly). All variations are wonderful, but my favorite so far is the cherry almond. My husband prefers chocolate chip. Even if you don't usually like scones, try this recipe. It's hard to go wrong here!

This is the best scone recipe I've tried so far. I chop the butter into the dry mix in a food processor and then add the sour cream/egg mixture and pulse a little more and it makes the lightest scone dough you've ever seen. The food processor makes the whole thing a snap to put together. You can add anything to this recipe but my favorite is a Tbsp of orange rind and a Tbsp of orange extract then glazed with confectioners sugar mixed with orange juice and marmalade - yum! Also, make 2 discs cut into 8 for 16 bite sized scones and bake for 10mins.

text:
I just finished my very first batch of scones and I loves them, the recepie is easy and it takes very little prep time. I didnt have a food procesor so I used a fork and for the butter I just put it in the freezer for an hour and used the fork to cut pieces and then used it to mix it with the dry ingredientes. The dough did come out sticky and it was hard to cut so I put it in freezer for 10-15 min and then used a floured knife to cut it and it was much easier. I did low the temp of the over to 350 and baked them for 18-20 min since at 400 my oven was browning them too fast. Over all after a bit of trail and error they came out great!!

I have made these numerous times and love them.  I have used cold butter - cut into sections over the dry ingredients, and using a Pampered Chef pastry blender (sharp edges) have been able to get the mixture to a crumbled blend appropriate to add the sour cream and egg.  I add a bit more sugar.  I finish the mixture by hand to get the dry and wet blended well.  
I bake them on a baking stone - and cut them into slices that end up yielding 16 (smaller portion = less calories :-)  
Just finished a chocolate chip version.  Delicious.

text:
Very good and very easy to make. I made the cranberry orange version using my food processor. I cut up the frozen butter into chunks and pulsed it with the dry ingredients then added in the wet and pulsed some more till it just comes together. Dumped it on a floured cutting board, formed it into the circle and cut it into 8 pieces. I skipped the sugar on top. After these cooled I drizzled on an icing that I had made with (not exact measurements) 1/3 cup confectioners sugar, 1 tsp milk, about half a tablespoon of room temp butter and a little bit of vanilla extract. Mixed it up all up and placed it in a ziplock bag, cut a corner off and drizzled away.

I hate to be one of those people, but I didn't have sour cream on hand. I used natural yogurt and half cream I had left over in the fridge (and needed to do something with the natural yogurt). text:
I've seriously made this recipe like 20 times and I love them every time. I tried a bunch of different combinations, but I have two favorites that seem to be a hit with everyone.  1. Cinnamon. I really don't measure much with spices so forgive my estimates, but I use about 1/2 cup of cinnamon chips and add a 1/4tsp of nutmeg. I've also put a pinch of allspice in. That was pretty nice. I'm thinking of trying a pumpkin scone, adding a bit of canned pumpkin with all of the same spices (probably not the chips though).  2. Orange and cranberry. I changed the footnote recipe a bit to bring out more flavor. I add 1/2 cup dried cranberries (craisins) and 2 tbsp. of orange marmalade to the sour cream and egg mixture. Because the marmalade will make it sticky, I just keep extra flour out to get back to the right constistency. This is my personal favorite! The orange zest just didn't cut it for me. I'm not very good at "zesting," and when I did you could barely tell the scones had orange flavor. I'd say like 2 tbsp. of orange juice (and a bit more flour) should do the trick too.

text:
4 stars because I had to make a few changes to get these right.  I tried 3 times before getting the perfect scones.   The first try, the scones turned out very dry and didn't rise much while baking.    The second time I used about 1 tbsp extra sour cream, and put about 1/8 cup less flour into the mixture, since flour was getting added while I handled the dough anyway.  These turned out great, but were still not quite dense enough to be perfect.  The third batch was perfect because I used half whole wheat flour, half all-purpose flour.  I added lemon zest and cranberries for the flavors.  This final batch was 5 stars.  I made the scones as described, without a food processor, and they turned out just fine.

My son had a class assignment to make a  food for one of his classes that represented a country that his family originated from.  So, we could choose from Scotland, Wales and Germany.  Scones are found in both Wales & Scotland so scones it was.  I didn't find it difficult at all to hand pinch the butter into the flour mixture--acutally, mixing it was very easy.  The only problem I had was that the scones tasted salty and the sweetness was overpowered by this salty taste.  I added a teaspoon of salt as was directed in the doubled recipe (16 scones), but if I make these again I would reduce the salt to 1/2 tsp. at most.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made these and couldn't wait for them to get to room temperature.  I ate them warm, so I don't know if the texture hadn't "set" yet, but I'm used to my scones being a little more crumbly.  Mine turned out a LITTLE bit cakier than crumbly, but it could be the changes/mistakes I made.  First of all, I totally forgot baking powder, so I only had baking soda in the mix (still puffed up fine).  I subbed fat free greek yogurt for sour cream.  Instead of white flour, I used 2 c whole wheat flour, which made the mix drier since it absorbs more liquid, so I did have to add about a tablespoon more yogurt.  My flavor variation was that I added a 1/2 cup of chopped assorted dried berries and 1 tsp of almond extract.  The taste is really delicious; aromatic, lightly sweet, nutty from the whole wheat, airy/light, not too heavy or dense, moist... yum!  The texture is not bad, just not what I expected from a scone, but let's see what it's like when it's cooled down.

text:
Addendum: I have now made this recipe or variations of it, no less than 30 times! It is a favorite of many co-workers.....they request them on their birthdays....for potlucks etc! My daughter's favorite version is Chocolate Chip Banana....mine is still Dark Chocolate Hazel Nut...another favorite is Pumpkin Chocolate Chip. 

Original Review 2008: I found this recipe yesterday morning and since then have made 5 batches. I have made 2 batches adding 2/3 c raisins and 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 batch adding 2/3 c white choc chips,1 batch with 2/3c white choc chips and 2/3 c dried cranberries and finally, 1 batch adding 2/3c dark choc chips and 1/2c chopped hazelnuts (my favorite!)I also used an egg wash and sprinkled the tops with washed raw sugar  before baking. Today is Easter and everyone is raving about the scones! Can't wait to take them to work tomorrow,if there are any left overs! Will make this one over and over for years to come!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe a lot and love it. I have tweaked it a lot and make two variations: Cherry Almond Vanilla, and Blueberry Almond. For both I use about 1/4 cup of ground blanched, skinned almonds. I have used skinned as well, they just have noticeable dark skins throughout, but still taste great. I also use 1/2 to 3/4 cup whole wheat flour and 1/4 cup dried plus 1/2 cup fresh blueberries or cherries, using all fresh fruit is too messy. The cherries are of course pitted and sliced in at least half. I rehydrate the dried fruit for about 10-20 min in boiling water, drain and use. I also use lite sour cream. Finally I add 1/2 teaspoon vanilla or almond extract. I use a 3 T cookie scoop to size them somewhat similarly. With wet hand I roll them in a ball and flatten them. I coat with a egg wash and sprinkle with sugar in the raw or turbinado sugar. With the scoop, it makes about 12 scones.
